metadata.title: On the Origin of Surface Traps in Colloidal II−VI Semiconductor Nanocrystals

sections.text:
Localized surface states are a ubiquitous characteristic ofsemiconductor surfaces, especially in the case of semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs) with very high fractions of surface atoms; this makes surface engineering a major task that is typically geared toward passivating the NC surface and optimizing optoelectronic performance by eliminating surface trapping of charge carriers.1−3 To guide such efforts, trap states are usually interpreted in terms of under-coordinated surface atoms whose dangling bonds result in electronic states within the semiconductor optical gap. The formation of traps can be induced by several factors: incomplete surface passivation during synthesis, oxidation of the surface by exposure to air, or by reaction with reducing/oxidizing ligands present in the reaction flask. Surfactant ligands have been used as a powerful tool to passivate the surface and eliminate such electronic traps. Ligands would presumably bind to under-coordinated surface atoms, and the resulting molecular orbitals could hybridize with valence and conduction band states to effectively passivate and remove the surface trap (Figure 1).4
To date, the most successful way to eliminate traps is by growing a different material around the nanocrystal in a core− shell structure.5 This has a significant impact on light-emitting devices because it allows one to achieve a photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of larger than 90%.6 On the other hand, the shell has the effect of insulating photoexcited charge carriers when colloidal nanocrystals are casted into films, leading to poor performances in optoelectronic applications that involve charge transport between neighboring dots. In these cases, the manipulation of surface ligands in core-only nanocrystals is paramount to achieve better efficiencies, but the presence of surface traps severely limits this. A major reason for this failure is a scarce knowledge of the nanocrystal surface chemistry. Understanding how ligands behave on the surface has been notoriously challenging, as it requires knowledge of the surface

termination at a level of detail that was not available until recently. Recent experimental studies on various metal chalcogenide nanocrystals, however, have shown that they are nonstoichiometric,1,7−12 featuring excess metal cations on their surfaces that are charge compensated by anionic ligands, such as carboxylates. Note that, for II−VI and IV−VI metal chalcogenide nanocrystals, charge compensation occurs at an exact 1:2 ratio between excess metal cations and anionic ligands. This makes the combined inorganic/organic hybrid system ef fectively stoichiometric, thus exhibiting, in principle, a clean band gap, free of midgap states.13
In general, ligand coordination to NC surfaces is now described using Green’s covalent bond classification scheme, which evaluates the number of electrons that a ligand uses to form bonds with the surface.14 Scheme 1 illustrates the
prevailing ligand types.10 Note that all ligands are drawn in their neutral form. L-type ligands are two-electron donors, i.e., Lewis bases such as amines that interact with Lewis acidic surface sites. X-type ligands (e.g., RCOO−) donate one electron to form a NC−ligand bond. Usually, X-type ligands behave as anionic species the compensate the excess of metal charge on NC surfaces.13 Z-type ligands are two-electron acceptors that
can interact with electron donating atoms on the NC surface. For example, surface chalcogen atoms have lone electron pairs that donate charge and bind metal salts such as cadmium carboxylates (Cd(O2CR)2), which can be seen as Z-type ligands. In this framework, the manipulation of trap states can also be understood in terms of Green’s notation: passivation with L-, X-, and Z-type ligands influences the coordination numbers of surface atoms and consequently may have a direct effect on the number of dangling bonds and the presence of traps; X-type ligands are linked to the presence surface traps that form when the 1:2 proportion between excess metal and X-type ligands, in II−VI and IV−VI colloidal nanocrystals, is broken.13 Experimental quantification of the number of X-type ligands at the surface is thus an important tool to verify whether a NC presents such a type of trap. Recent NMR studies, however, indicate that zincblende CdSe NCs feature an almost exact 1:2 ratio between excess Cd and oleate ligands.9 This indicates that trap states may stem mostly from under-coordinated surface atoms within a fixed 1:2 ratio between excess metal and X-type ligands. This is in contrast with the accepted view that ef fectively stoichiometric NCs are trap free.13 Understanding then the role of L-, X-, and Z-type surface passivation on the electronic structure of these NCs becomes crucial to find the origin of trap states. Additionally, CdSe NCs exhibit typical surface ligand concentrations of 3 ligands/nm2,10 well below the surface atom density, suggesting that not all metal atoms at the surface are passivated. Despite this, and as anticipated earlier, several theoretical works based on density functional theory (DFT) indicate that, even with these low ligand concentrations, nonstoichiometric Cd chalcogenide NCs, fully charge compensated by X-type ligands, i.e., NCs ef fectively stoichiometric, can exhibit nominally trap-free bandgaps.15,16 These qualitative observations suggest that not all under-coordinated surface atoms are sources of traps. Recently, Anderson et al.10 reported an almost step-like decrease of the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of CdSe NCs upon reducing the Cd carboxylate coverage below 3 nm−2, which is obtained by inducing Z-type displacement by L-type ligands. This strongly indicates that the removal of Z-type ligands from the CdSe surface introduces surface trap states.16 This conclusion was corroborated by the finding that reducing the Cd carboxylate coverage of CdSe NCs leads to hole trapping.17 Clearly, such observations call for a detailed assessment of the atomic configurations present at NC surfaces and their role in inducing midgap electronic states. This goes well beyond the prevailing qualitative picture of surface passivation, which fails to account for the diversity of surface atom/ligand interactions and cannot explain how each of these interactions affect the electronic structure. In recent years, theoretical modeling has been very helpful in understanding with greater detail the electronic structure of colloidal nanocrystals. Calculations have also been employed to understand the mechanism of trapping; however, in most of these works, traps are induced by voluntarily changing the 1:2 ratio between excess metal and X-type ligands, i.e., by making NCs ef fectively nonstoichiometric. This is the case for DFT calculations by Voznyy et al., Grossman and co-workers, Prezhdo and co-workers, and Zherebetskyy et al. for small and large Cd and Pb chalcogenide systems.18−22 Califano and coworkers made an interesting effort to provide a universal trapping mechanism on a wide range of II−VI colloidal NCs
Scheme 1. Different Types of Ligands Found on the Surface of Metal Chalcogenide Nanocrystalsa aThe oxidation state of the metal on the surface is shown in parentheses.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
753
using tight-binding calculations.23−26 However, an important limitation of their methodological approach is that surface atoms are capped with pseudoatoms, usually employed to recover the coordination of bulk atoms. In this model, trap states are observed when capped atoms, as a sort of X-type ligands, are selectively removed from the surface as neutral species, ultimately lifting the 1:2 ratio. In addition, after removal of these pseudoatoms, the surface is kept frozen, neglecting surface reconstruction that could help in spontaneously healing the surface from traps. Many previous theoretical works have also analyzed the effect of ligand passivation on the electronic structure and the dynamics of photoexcited states of CdSe NCs. However, most of these works study the effect of L-type ligands on small wurtzite CdSe clusters with 1:1 Cd/Se ratio27−34 or the effect of replacing X-type ligands with others of the same type for larger ef fectively stoichiometric NCs.35 No study that we are aware of has ever analyzed the effect of displacing Z-type ligands from the NC surface. Here, we implement density functional theory (DFT) calculations to perform a systematic study on the atomic and electronic structure of zincblende ME (M = Cd, Zn and E = S, Se, Te) nanocrystal surfaces as a function of their surface termination. We start our discussion with a Cd68Se55Cl26 NC, but we also show that these results are general and apply to larger NCs and the whole family of II−VI zincblende NCs. In our approach, we allow for full relaxation of the atomic structure to correctly capture the effect of surface reconstruction on the electronic structure. We always preserve a 1:2 ratio between excess metal cations and X-type chloride anions to maintain charge neutral NCs and a closed shell electronic configuration in the thermodynamically preferred configuration. This means that for all our calculations NCs are ef fectively stoichiometric. We then monitor the density of states following: (i) the effect of L- and X-type ligands and their replacement with other ligand types and (ii) the displacement of Z-type ligands from the NC surface. We show that in the latter case doubly coordinated chalcogenide ions on the NC surface generate localized states within the optical gap, while similarly under-coordinated metal atoms do not. The difference can be explained by analyzing the molecular orbitals of the doubly coordinated surface atoms, which in the case of chalcogenide atoms has a nonbonding lone-pair np orbital that is orthogonal to the adjacent metal (n + 1)s orbitals and is highly localized. This simplified localized MO picture captures the influence of the surface atom coordination numbers on the electronic energy levels and explains the formation of trap states. This result clearly singles out 2-coordinated chalcogenide surface ions as the cause for suboptimal optoelectronic properties and hence provides a clear handle to improve the performance of NC optoelectronic devices.
■ MODEL Cd68Se55 NANOCRYSTAL: SURFACE STRUCTURE
A zincblende nanocrystal cluster, Cd68Se55Cl26, has been chosen as a model system for our calculations. Corresponding to a diameter of 1.8 nm, this model size is both advantageous from a computational standpoint and relevant from an experimental point of view. This model NC features a nonstoichiometric Cd/ Se ratio of 1.24 and exposes four Se rich (1̅1 ̅1 ̅), four Cd rich (111), and six Cd rich (100) facets (see Figure 2). To compensate for the Cd excess and generate an ef fectively stoichiometric NC, we imposed charge neutrality in the model
system by adding 26 chloride anions, 24 of which end up on the (100) surfaces and 2 are placed at the edge between the (111) and the (100) facets. We thus assumed that each excess Cd atom possesses a closed shell electronic configuration and the +2 oxidation state. The (100) facets feature Cd atoms in two configurations, tetra- (Cd-4c) and tricoordinated (Cd-3c), respectively. Note that the (100) facet is only composed of Cd-4c and Cd-3c atoms that are shared with one or two additional facets and can then be identified as edge and vertex atoms, respectively. The (1 ̅1 ̅1̅) facets present also edge and vertex Cd atoms next to two configurations specific to this facet, i.e., tricoordinated (Se-3c) and tetra-coordinated (Cd-4c). Finally, the (111) facets contain, in addition to Cd vertex atoms, two (111) specific configurations, classified as 4-coordinated Se (Se-4c) and tricoordinated Cd (Cd-3c). Strikingly, both Cd-3c and Se-4c atoms on the (111) almost lie in the same plane, with a 200° rather than 180° dihedral angle. This apparently is a consequence of the strain induced by the Cd-3c atoms that prefer an almost trigonal planar configuration. Table S1 contains a summary of the coordination numbers for all atoms on the surface of the pristine Cd68Se55Cl26 NC (column with 0 CdCl2 group displaced), again showing that the surface is composed of both tri- and tetra-coordinated Cd and Se atoms.
■ MODEL Cd68Se55 NANOCRYSTAL: ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE
Figure 3a shows the computed electronic energy levels of the pristine Cd68Se55Cl26 NC. A significant discretization of the molecular orbitals (MOs) is evident in the conduction band (CB), while the density of states (DOS) in the valence band (VB) is almost continuous. This asymmetry is well-known for CdSe NCs and stems from the contribution of the 3-fold
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
754
degenerate 4p orbitals from Se atoms to the VB versus 1-fold degenerate 5s orbitals of Cd contributing to the CB. As has been documented previously, DFT/PBE underestimates the bandgap, in this case by more than 1 eV.36 Each MO was further analyzed in terms of its atomic component orbitals. The atomic orbital contributions were categorized according to the coordination of the atoms described in Figure 2 above (e.g., 3- coordinate selenium, (Se-3c)) and represented by a colored segment. The length of the colored section represents the fractional contribution of that species to the MO (Figure 3a). This approach makes it possible to analyze the MOs according to their location in the NC. For example, it can be seen in Figure 3a that Cd-3c and Cd-4c contribute almost equally to the MOs in the CB. Se-3c and Cd-4c on the other hand contribute the most to the VB MOs. Contour plots of the MOs at the valence- and conductionband edges are also shown in Figure 3a. The lowest energy orbitals of the CB are fully delocalized with superatomic S and P envelopes as predicted by a simple particle-in-a-box model for spherical NCs. However, the degeneracy of the p orbital states is lifted due to the asymmetry induced by the different types of facets exposed at the surface. As shown below, the HOMO and LUMO levels are delocalized band-edge states and not localized surface states. Hence, despite the presence of atoms with different coordination numbers, the model Cd68Se55 nanocrystal presents a clean band gap; i.e., no midgap states intrude between the depicted MOs at the top of the VB and the bottom of the CB. We sought an impartial method to identify surface localized states that could trap charge carriers. Orbital localization can be assessed by the inverse participation ratio (IPR)37,38 of an electronic state, a quantity defined as

Here, Pα,i represents the weight of molecular orbital i on a given atom α expanded in an atomic orbital basis. For finite systems, the IPR provides an estimate of the number of atoms that
contribute to a given electronic state i. It can range from 1 in the case of a localized state to a single atom to the number of atoms in the system when the wave function is distributed equally over all atoms in the system. Figure 3b shows the IPR calculated for the different MOs of the Cd68Se55Cl26 NC versus their energy. In general, MOs belonging to the CB are more delocalized than those in the VB, as a consequence of the larger number of equivalent Cd atomic orbitals in which the wave function can delocalize. Certain MOs deep in the VB, at around −7.5 eV, present some degree of localization, i.e., a low IPR. Inspection of these states shows that they are composed mostly (more than 50%) of 3p orbitals on two Cl atoms at the (100) surface. This is of interest because other types of halide ligands, e.g., iodide, may push these localized states closer to the VB edge, providing a potential source of traps.
■ MODEL Cd68Se55 NANOCRYSTAL: COORDINATION NUMBERS
Despite the presence of dangling bonds at the Cd-3c and Se-3c surface atoms, there are no localized midgap states within the band gap of the pristine ef fectively stoichiometric model nanocrystal. In fact, as can be seen in Figure 3a, Cd-3c and Se-3c contribute to delocalized VB and CB states. While this point can be inferred from previous DFT works,15,16,35 it is still quite remarkable because it stands in contrast to a simple MO picture where any dangling bond contributes a midgap state, as presented in Figure 1. To understand the origin of the pristine optical gap, despite the presence of Cd-3c and Se-3c, we sought an atomistic understanding of the interaction of these surface atoms with the valence and conduction band states. In Figure S1, we illustrate the MOs for the 3-coordinated species predicted by a localized crystal field theory picture. When the surface reconstructs, both Cd-3c and Se-3c reach more stable “local” conformations by distorting away from tetrahedral angles (109.5°). In Figure S1a (left side), we show that Cd-3c atoms approach a trigonal planar structure that leads to a more favorable interaction
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
755
between the Cd 5s orbital and negative charges of the Se ions that widen the orbital splitting. Selenium on the other hand further pyramidalizes, with all Se 4p orbitals participating with a favorable interaction with the Cd ions. This lowers the energy of the Se 4p orbitals into the valence band where they hybridize with the delocalized states. If, on the other hand, the trigonal planar configuration had been favored, at least one of the Se 4p orbitals would be nonbonding and fall within the gap. Reconstruction of this kind has been discussed in numerous experimental and theoretical studies on metal chalcogenide surfaces.39−41 These reconstructions push the filled and empty orbitals of Cd-3c and Se-3c into the conduction and valence bands, respectively, leading to hybridization with the delocalized states and a pristine optical gap.
■ L-TYPE LIGAND ADDITION In addition to typical X-type carboxylate ligands that bind to surface Cd atoms,9 L-type ligands like amines, thiols, phosphines, or phosphine oxides can bind under-coordinated surface Cd atoms.42 To study the effect of passivating the Cd-3c atoms on the (111) surfaces, we calculated the electronic structure following adsorption of primary amines or alkyl thiols. Figure 4a displays the electronic states of Cd68Se55Cl26L22 NCs with L = CH3NH2 or CH3SH, decomposed into atomic orbital contributions from the ligands and the core. Both amine and thiol ligands contribute with orbital density to states well within the bands and cause a small decrease of the bandgap. Further,
L-type ligand adsorption reduces the polarization induced by the facets and decreases the splitting between the Pe superatomic orbitals. In addition, adsorption of the electron donating ligands raises the energy of both the conduction and valence band edges by more than 1 eV toward vacuum, an effect used to engineer band offsets in quantum dot solar cells and usually described as a surface dipole shift in the literature.43−45
For both amine and thiol adsorbed Cd68Se55Cl26L22 NCs, we also computed the IPR to assess the influence of L-type ligands on the delocalization of the MOs. As evident from Figure 4b, all models show a similar trend with MOs well delocalized over the whole NC, despite the change of all (111) Cd surface atoms from 3- to 4-coordination.
■ X-TYPE LIGAND REPLACEMENT To assess the influence of the X-type ligand on the band structure, we analyzed the replacement of chloride ligands for thiolate ligands. Figure 5a illustrates the resulting MOs, which are raised in energy toward the vacuum level. The band gap also shrinks by 0.2 eV, an effect previously reported upon the exchange of carboxylates for thiolates35,46 and attributed to the delocalization of the electronic wave functions over the sulfur atoms in the thiolate moiety. However, despite the welldocumented trapping of holes with thiol/thiolate ligands,47−49 no electronic states appear within the optical gap and all MOs remain delocalized (IPR > 5) (Figure 5b). However, a
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
756
significant contribution from the thiolate sulfur to the VB edge is visible, which could be related to the low photoluminescence quantum yield of CdSe nanocrystals with thiolate ligands.47−49
■ Z-TYPE LIGAND DISPLACEMENT To investigate the effect of Z-type ligands on the surface passivation, we followed a step-by-step procedure in which CdCl2 moieties have been displaced one at the time from the Cd68Se55Cl26 NC. As many product structures can result, we decided to limit our study to structures where displacement involves a pair of Cl atoms bound to the same Cd atom. Afterward, the NC structure was relaxed and its MOs calculated to assess the relation between CdCl2 displacement and midgap state formation. As shown in Figure 2, the Cd68Se55Cl26 NC has the majority of its chloride ligands on the (100) surfaces, bound to cadmium at edges and/or vertices. We studied the electronic structure on displacing between one and ten CdCl2 units and began by removing a vertex site. As can be seen in Table S1, this leads to a significant change in the coordination numbers of the surface atoms. In particular, as shown in Figure 6a (top), displacing the first CdCl2 unit exposes a Cd-3c and a Se-2c. DFT calculations show that even after reconstruction a midgap state is formed that is highly localized on the Se-2c atom. An orbital density plot of this MO (Figure 7a) shows that the midgap state is composed primarily of a single Se 4p atomic orbital on the
exposed Se-2c atom. Hence, Se-2c atoms provide a localized, occupied MO within the band gap, a likely hole trap.16,17 The electronic structure in the CB on the other hand is minimally affected because the Cd atoms preserve a Cd-3c or Cd-4c coordination. Further evidence of this is shown in the IPR plot in Figure 6b where a localized state with an IPR close to 1, i.e., a MO localized on one atom, appears inside the bandgap. Successive displacement of additional CdCl2 fragments increases the number of Se-2c atoms on the NC surface (Table S1). In some cases, removal of CdCl2 induces a reconstruction that eliminates the newly formed Se-2c by allowing it to bind a nearby Cd atom. Displacement of CdCl2 also creates Cd-2c centers that relax to a bond angle as large as 160° after surface reconstruction. The MOs formed after displacement of 1−4 CdCl2 fragments and structural relaxation are shown in Figure S2. Whereas each Se-2c atom consistently leads to a localized midgap state, the 5s atomic orbitals on Cd2c atoms mix with orbitals in the CB (black segments in Figures S2 and S3) and no localized Cd centered MOs are formed. We thus conclude that only Se-2c atoms form localized states, whereas Cd-2c does not. In the absence of electronic doping, these Se-2c orbitals will be occupied and can serve as hole traps. This is in line with the observation that hole trapping limits the PLQY in CdSe NCs following displacement of cadmium carboxylate.17 We note that shifting the Fermi-level downward, by intentional or unintentional doping, may empty
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
757
the Se-2c orbitals converting them into electron traps, as we have previously observed in films of CdTe NCs.16,50
■ 2-COORDINATED Se ATOMS AS A SOURCE OF TRAPS: A MO PICTURE
To understand why Se-2c atoms, but not Cd-2c atoms, form trap states in the band gap, we analyzed the chemical bonding between Cd and Se at the NC surface as we have done above
for Cd-3c and Se-3c atoms. We chose the Cd65Se55Cl20 NC model as it exhibits both Cd-2c and Se-2c atoms, along with the atoms of higher coordination. As shown in Figure S4a, a linear conformation is the most stable geometry for Cd-2c because it strengthens the interaction with the negatively charged Se ions while minimizing the repulsive interaction between the Se anions. This reconstruction raises the 5s orbital energy into the CB, leading to hybridization and delocalized orbitals, as was seen in Figure S1.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
758
In the case of the Se-2c atom, the orbital splitting depends on the Cd−Se−Cd angle. In a bent configuration (Figure S4b), two of the 4p orbitals of Se are split by the crystal field of the surrounding cadmium ions. The remaining Se 4p orbital is orthogonal to the cadmium ions and is therefore nonbonding. In a linear geometry, one 4p orbital has the appropriate symmetry for bonding and has a strong interaction with the neighboring selenium centers; however, it leaves two orbitals that are orthogonal to the adjacent cadmium orbitals and are thus nonbonding. The DFT minimized structure shows a bent configuration at the Se-2c confirming the presence of a single nonbonding level. This nonbonding Se 4p level creates the localized midgap electronic state described in Figure 7a. Alternatively, this same bond can be described using group theory by assigning a local C2v symmetry (Figure 7b) to the surrounding region of the Se-2c atom. All orbitals of the same symmetry mix with each other, with the exception of the 4px orbital (b1 irreducible representation) that is orthogonal to the symmetry adapted combination of the 5s Cd orbitals (a1 and b2 symmetry). We also noticed that, when up to 10 displaced CdCl2 moieties (Table S1) are involved, all Cd and Se atoms are at least 2-coordinated. This means that monocoordinated surface atoms are likely very reactive and will always find some nearby atoms to bind to. On the basis of these results, we constructed a new molecular orbital diagram (Figure 8) for CdSe NCs that
expands the information on Scheme 1. The valence atomic orbitals of the metal and the chalcogenide atoms include the 5s and 4p shells, respectively. The interaction between Cd and Se involves atoms with different coordination numbers. For any coordination, the Cd 5s orbital will always be mixed with orbitals inside the CB, as we have seen in the previous section. Due to the isotropy of the Cd 5s orbitals, they have the appropriate symmetry to interact with the neighboring Se atoms regardless of the coordination number or geometry. This
interaction raises the energy of the Cd 5s orbitals enough for them to couple to other 5s orbitals in the CB. As a result, surface Cd atoms are less likely to be a source of surface trap states. Se 4p orbitals, on the other hand, can be orthogonal to neighboring atoms, which in the case of Se-2c leads to localized nonbonding orbitals that fall near the middle of the optical gap. A second effect, also depicted in Figure 8, is that in CdSe the width of the conduction band is larger than the width of the valence band, as also evidenced by the large difference in effective masses for electrons and holes. This means that the required perturbation of Cd 5s surface orbitals to reach the CB is smaller than the required perturbation of Se 4p orbitals to reach the VB. This MO picture is very useful not only for its simplicity but also because it provides the requirement that surface chalcogenide atoms have coordination numbers larger than two as a necessary condition for a NC to have a band gap free of midgap states. This also explains why the photoluminescence of CdSe NC can be recovered by adding Z-type ligands as demonstrated in the work of Anderson et al.10 The Z-type ligand is an electron acceptor that can easily bind to the lonepair 4p orbital of the Se-2c atoms. When this happens, the coordination number changes from Se-2c to Se-3c, thus removing midgap states and reducing the efficiency of trapmediated recombination.
■ GENERALIZATION TO LARGER SIZES, DIFFERENT LIGANDS, AND OTHER METAL CHALCOGENIDE MATERIALS
Finally, we verified the general applicability of the arguments above to larger NC sizes, other Z-type ligands, and other II−VI materials. For this purpose, we displaced one CdCl2 Z-type ligand from a vertex site in a 3.0 nm zincblende CdSe NC (Cd333Se297Cl78) (Figure S5). We then performed a structural relaxation at the same level of theory employed for the smaller NC model, and we noticed the presence of a 2-coordinated Se atom that introduces a midgap state in the bandgap of the material. The same effect is visible when Cd(formate)2 is displaced from a CdSe NC fully passivated with formate ligands, which emulate the carboxylate groups (oleates) employed in the experiments (Figure S6). Additionally, we analyzed a similar Z-type displacement for the whole family of zincblende ME (M= Cd, Zn; E = S, Se, Te) semiconductor NCs and all of them show a similar pattern (Figure S7). In this framework, we expect that these 2-coordinated chalcogenide atoms are a source of traps also for other nanocrystals with equivalent crystalline structures, like for example the III−V family, as well as for different shapes, like nanorods and nanoplatelets that expose similar facets.
■ CONCLUSIONS In summary, we have studied the effect of L-, X-, and Z-type ligands on the electronic structure of CdSe NCs and have demonstrated that midgap states appear when chemical modification at the surface leads to the presence of dicoordinated chalcogenide atoms. L-type and X-type ligands only marginally influence the orbital energy levels, with the most relevant contribution being a shift of the band edges relative to vacuum. On the other hand, Z-type ligands have a profound impact on the electronic structure of colloidal NCs when they are displaced from the surface. In particular, the formation of 2-coordinated selenium atoms provide a source of
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04648 Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 752−761
759
midgap states that can act as charge carrier traps in agreement with previous experimental works. These midgap states are formed by nonbonding Se 4p orbitals that are orthogonal to the adjacent cadmium 5s orbitals and are highly localized. This simplified localized MO picture captures the influence of the surface atoms coordination numbers on the electronic energy levels and explains the formation of trap states. These results are general and also apply to larger NC sizes, other Z-type ligands, other zincblende II−VI NCs, and different shapes.
■ METHODS We have carried out atomistic simulations at the Density Functional Theory (DFT)51 level using the PBE exchange-correlation functional52 and a double-ζ basis set as implemented in the CP2k quantum chemical package.53 Relativistic effects for all atoms are included using effective core-potentials. All structures have been optimized in the gas phase. More details on how the structures have been constructed are given in the text.

metadata.abstractText: One of the greatest challenges in the field of semiconductor nanomaterials is to make trap-free nanocrystalline structures to attain a remarkable improvement of their optoelectronic performances. In semiconductor nanomaterials, a very high number of atoms is located on the surface and these atoms form the main source of electronic traps. The relation between surface atom coordination and electronic structure, however, remains largely unknown. Here, we use density functional theory to unveil the surface structure/ electronic property relations of zincblende II−VI CdSe model nanocrystals, whose stoichiometry and surface termination agree with recent experimental findings. On the basis of the analysis of the surface geometry and the recent classification of the ligand surface coordination in terms of L-, X-, and Z-type ligands, we show that, contrary to expectations, most under-coordinated “dangling” atoms do not form traps and that Land X-type ligands are benign to the nanocrystal electronic structure. On the other hand, we find clear evidence that Z-type displacement induces midgap states, localized on the 4p lone pair of 2-coordinated selenium surface atoms. We generalize our findings to the whole family of II−VI metal chalcogenide nanocrystals of any size and shape and propose a new schematic representation of the chemical bond in metal chalcogenide nanocrystals that includes explicitly the coordination number of surface atoms. This work results in a detailed understanding of the formation of surface traps and provides a clear handle for further optimization of colloidal nanocrystals for optoelectronics applications. L surface states are a ubiquitous characteristic of semiconductor surfaces, especially in the case of semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs) with very high fractions of surface atoms; this makes surface engineering a major task that is typically geared toward passivating the NC surface and optimizing optoelectronic performance by eliminating surface trapping of charge carriers. To guide such efforts, trap states are usually interpreted in terms of under-coordinated surface atoms whose dangling bonds result in electronic states within the semiconductor optical gap. The formation of traps can be induced by several factors: incomplete surface passivation during synthesis, oxidation of the surface by exposure to air, or by reaction with reducing/oxidizing ligands present in the reaction flask. Surfactant ligands have been used as a powerful tool to passivate the surface and eliminate such electronic traps. Ligands would presumably bind to under-coordinated surface atoms, and the resulting molecular orbitals could hybridize with valence and conduction band states to effectively passivate and remove the surface trap (Figure 1). To date, the most successful way to eliminate traps is by growing a different material around the nanocrystal in a core− shell structure. This has a significant impact on light-emitting devices because it allows one to achieve a photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of larger than 90%. On the other hand, the shell has the effect of insulating photoexcited charge carriers when colloidal nanocrystals are casted into films, leading to poor performances in optoelectronic applications that involve charge transport between neighboring dots. In these cases, the manipulation of surface ligands in core-only nanocrystals is paramount to achieve better efficiencies, but the presence of surface traps severely limits this. A major reason for this failure is a scarce knowledge of the nanocrystal surface chemistry.
